title: Health service utilisation among regular methamphetamine users
drugs_free_text: The majority of participants (82%) had used methamphetamine at least weekly in the past year and 13% had used daily. Polydrug use was common, with a median of seven drug classes used in the past year (range 2-11). Fifty-five percent of the sample reported methamphetamine to be their drug of choice. The next most commonly reported drugs of choice were cannabis, ecstasy and heroin (12% each). Approximately three quarters (72%) of the sample had ever injected a drug, and two thirds (65%) nominated injecting as their main route of methamphetamine administration during the past year.

Of the remaining participants, 27% reported only recent amphetamine injection (n=34), 48% reported injecting neither heroin nor amphetamine but other drugs, predominantly pharmaceutical opiates (n=60) and 25% had abstained from drug injection in the past month (n=31). One third of participants (35%) were prescribed OST at the time of interview

title: Health service utilisation among regular methamphetamine users
drugs_free_text: The majority of participants (82%) had used methamphetamine at least weekly in the past year and 13% had used daily. Polydrug use was common, with a median of seven drug classes used in the past year (range 2-11). Fifty-five percent of the sample reported methamphetamine to be their drug of choice. The next most commonly reported drugs of choice were cannabis, ecstasy and heroin (12% each). Approximately three quarters (72%) of the sample had ever injected a drug, and two thirds (65%) nominated injecting as their main route of methamphetamine administration during the past year.

title: Long-term outcomes after residential substance use treatment: Relapse, morbidity, and mortality.
region: Hampton, eastern Virginia / northeast North Carolina
data_source: Patients discharged from a Veterans Affairs (VA), Mental Health Residential Recovery Program (MHRRTP), linked to national VA health records
drugs_free_text: Discharged from residential substance abuse programme. The most commonly identified drug of choice was cocaine (63%, n = 130), followed by alcohol (29%, n = 60), opioids (6%, n = 12), and other such as methamphetamine, synthetic cannabinoids etc. (2%, n = 4). However, most veterans stated they used more than one substance: 74% of those with cocaine use disorder also had a diagnosis of alcohol use dis- order, 77% (n = 159) of those with opiate use disorder had a diagnosis of alcohol use disorder, and 60% (n = 124) of those with other drug use disorder also had a diagnosis of alcohol use disorder. Therefore, overall, 73% (n = 151) of veterans had both alcohol use disorder and another sub-stance use disorder.
